question:
Assertion (A): The Congress in all the provinces resigned in the year 1939. (UPSC Prelims 2008)

Reason (R): The Congress did not accept the decision of the Viceroy to declare war against Germany in the context of the Second World War
option_1: Both A and R are individually true and R is the correct explanation of A.
option_2: Both A and R are individually true but R is not the correct explanation of A
option_3: A is True but R is false
option_4: A is false but R is true
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • The Congress ministries resigned in October and November 1939. The resignations were a protest against Viceroy Lord Linlithgow’s decision to declare India a belligerent in World War II without consulting the elected representatives of the Indian people.

Other reasons for the resignations include:

1. The Congress was unable to form ministries in four provinces.

2. The emergence of a “left wing” in the Congress made it impossible for the ministries to function.

3. There were widespread communal disturbances in their provinces.

  • The statement “The Congress did not accept the decision of the Viceroy to declare war against Germany in the context of the Second World War” is true.
  • In 1939, the Congress Party resigned in protest against Viceroy Lord Linlithgow’s decision to involve India in World War II without the consent of the Indian people.
  • The Congress ministries resigned in October and November 1939.
  • On December 22, 1939, the Muslim League observed “Day of Deliverance” in protest of the Viceroy’s decision.

In 1940, Viceroy Linlithgow made the August Offer, which included:

1. Expanding the Executive Council of the Viceroy of India to include more Indians

2. Establishing an advisory war council

3. Giving full weight to minority opinion

4. Recognizing Indians’ right to frame their own constitution

question: Who among the following rejected the title of knighthood and refused to accept a position in the Council of the Secretary of State for India? (UPSC Prelims 2008)
option_1: Motilal Nehru
option_2: M.G. Ranade
option_3: G.K. Gokhale
option_4: B.G. Tilak
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • Gopal Krishna Gokhale rejected the title of knighthood and refused to accept a position in the Council of the Secretary of State for India. Gokhale was a social reformer, educationist, and social and political leader during the Indian Independence Movement. He was born on May 9, 1866 in Kotluk village in present-day Maharashtra. He worked for social empowerment, education expansion, and India’s freedom for three decades.
  • Gokhale said that by accepting honors he would cease to be Gopal Krishna Gokhale. He was a member of the Bombay Legislative Council from 1899 to 1902 and the Imperial Legislative Council from 1902 until his death.

question: Who among the following Gandhian followers was a teacher by Profession? (UPSC Prelims 2008)
option_1: A.N. Sinha
option_2: Braj Kishore Prasad
option_3: J. B. Kriplani
option_4: Rajendra Prasad
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • J. B. Kripalani was a teacher before becoming a full-time political activist and a follower of Gandhi. Kripalani’s full name is Jivatram Bhagwandas Kriplani. He taught English and history at several institutions, including Benaras Hindu University. Kripalani is known for his role in spreading Gandhian principles and educating people about nonviolence and self-reliance. Kripalani met with Gandhi in 1917 during the Champaran Satyagraha.

question: Which one of the following suggested the reconstitution of the Viceroy’s Executive council in which all the portfolios including that of War Members were to be held by the Indian leader? (UPSC Prelims 2008)
option_1: Simon Commission
option_2: Shimla Conference
option_3: Cripps Proposal
option_4: Cabinet Mission
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • The Wavell Plan, also known as the Shimla Conference, proposed the reconstitution of the Viceroy’s Executive Council in 1945. The plan suggested that all members of the Viceroy’s Executive Council, except the Viceroy and the Commander-in-Chief, would be Indians.
  • The plan also suggested that all portfolios, including that of War Members, would be held by Indian leaders. The Simla conference was held in 1945 under the presidency of Lord Wavell and Indian political leaders.

The Simon Commission :

  • It is also known as the Indian Statutory Commission, was a group of seven British Parliament members who studied constitutional reform in India in 1927. The commission was appointed by the British Conservative government in November 1927 to report on the working of the Indian constitution. The commission’s chairman was Sir John Simon.
  • The Simon Commission’s recommendations included giving more autonomy to Indian provincial governments, but keeping a veto for the Viceroy. The Simon Report was important in the constitutional discussion that led to the Government of India Act of 1935.
  • The commission was boycotted by Indians because all its members were Englishmen and the commission had no Indian member. The slogan “Simon Go Back” became one of the most enduring slogans of the Indian freedom struggle.

The Cripps Mission :

  • It was a meeting between British government representatives and Indian leaders that took place from March 22 to April 11, 1942. The mission’s purpose was to secure Indian cooperation and support for the British war efforts in World War II. The mission’s proposals were constitutional and sought Indian support.
  • The mission was organized by Sir Richard Stafford Cripps, a member of the War Cabinet.
  • The mission failed and the issue of India’s constitution was postponed until the end of the war. The mission’s failure led to the Quit India Movement, a countrywide strike wave that involved workers, peasants, and states’ peoples.

The mission’s proposals included:

1. Establishing the Indian Union

2. Allowing India to participate in international bodies and the United Nations

3. The Constituent Assembly would have members nominated by the Provincial Assemblies as well as the Princely States

4. Any Province, which is not prepared to accept the new Constitution would have the right to sign a separate agreement with Britain regarding its future status

  • The Muslim League criticized the idea of a single Indian Union. They also stated that the proposals denied the Muslims the right to self-determination and the creation of Pakistan.

The Cabinet Mission Plan :

  • It was a proposal put forward by the British Cabinet Mission in 1946 to address the issue of Indian independence. It recommended the creation of a united India with a federal structure, granting significant autonomy to provinces, while ensuring protections for minorities. However, it failed to gain acceptance from Indian political leaders and ultimately led to the partition of India and the creation of Pakistan.

question: During the Indian Freedom Struggle, Who of the following raised an army called ‘Free Indian Legion”? (UPSC Prelims 2008)
option_1: Lala Hardayal
option_2: Rashbehari Bose
option_3: Subhas Chandra Bose
option_4: V. D. Savarkar
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • Subhas Chandra Bose, also known as Netaji, raised the Free Indian Legion in 1914 during World War II. The legion was made up of prisoners of war and was also known as the “Tiger Legion”.
  • Bose, a prominent leader of the Indian National Congress, believed that India’s freedom could only be achieved through armed struggle. He came to Berlin in 1941 to seek German aid and form the legion as part of his efforts to win India’s independence.

question: Who among the following gave a systematic critique of the moderate politics of the Indian National Congress in a series of articles entitled new Lamps for Old? (UPSC Prelims 2008)
option_1: Aurobindo Ghosh
option_2: R.C.Dutt
option_3: Syed Ahmad khan
option_4: Viraraghavachari
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • In 1893–94, Sri Aurobindo Ghosh wrote a series of articles titled “New Lamps for Old” that critically examined the moderate politics of the Indian National Congress. Aurobindo Ghosh is known as the Father of Indian Extremism. He is also the author of Savitri.

question: Who among the following used the phrase ‘Un-British to criticize the English colonial control of India? (UPSC Prelims 2008)
option_1: Anandmohan Bose
option_2: Badruddin Tyabji
option_3: Dadabhai Naoroji
option_4: Pherozeshah Mehta
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • Dadabhai Naoroji used the phrase “Un British” to criticize the English colonial control of India. In 1901, Naoroji published Poverty and Un-British Rule in India, which highlights how British economic policies extracted wealth from India to finance their industries. This theory is known as the “Drain of Wealth”.
  • Naoroji was a Parsi scholar, writer, and politician who was also the officialambassador of India. He was the first Indian to become a member of the British Parliament, and was a three-time Congress president in 1886, 1893, and 1906.

question: Who was the Viceroy of India when the Rowlatt Act was Passed? (UPSC Prelims 2008)
option_1: Lord Irwin
option_2: Lord Readin
option_3: Lord Chelmsford
option_4: Lord Wavell
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • Lord Chelmsford was the Viceroy of India when the Rowlatt Act was passed in 1919. The Rowlatt Act, also known as the Anarchical and Revolutionary Crimes Act of 1919, was intended to continue the wartime emergency powers of the executive branch.
  • Chelmsford was concerned about the growing nationalist movement in India and spearheaded the passage of the Rowlatt Acts. The Rowlatt Act was passed despite opposition from Indians, with every single Indian member of the Central Legislative Council opposing it.
  • Chelmsford’s administration oversaw its implementation, which further intensified the Indian independence movement.

question: Which one of the following began with the Dandi March? (UPSC Prelims 2009)
option_1: Home Rule Movement
option_2: Non-Cooperation Movement
option_3: Civil Disobedience Movement
option_4: Quit India Movement
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • Mahatma Gandhi’s Dandi March, also known as the Salt March, began with the Civil Disobedience Movement on March 12, 1930. The march started from Sabarmati Ashram with 78 people and ended on April 6, 1930, when Gandhi broke the law by making salt from seawater at Dandi, a village in Gujarat.

question: In the context of the Indian freedom struggle 16th October 1905 is well known for which one of the following reasons? (UPSC Prelims 2009)
option_1: The formal proclamation of Swadeshi Movement was made in Calcutta town hall
option_2: Partition of Bengal took effect
option_3: Dadabhai Naoroji declared that the goal of Indian National Congress was Swaraj
option_4: Lokmanya Tilak started Swadeshi Movement in Poona
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • October 16, 1905 is known for the Partition of Bengal. The Viceroy of India, Lord Curzon, announced the decision to divide Bengal on July 19, 1905.
  • The partition came into effect on October 16, 1905, and was observed as a day of mourning and fasting throughout Bengal.
  • Curzon cited ease of administration as the reason for the decision, but it was actually meant to curb rising nationalist sentiments in Bengal.
  • On August 7, 1905, a mass protest was organized in Calcutta’s Town Hall. Ramendra Sunder Trivedi called for observance of arandhan (keeping the hearth unlit) as a mark of mourning and protest on the day the partition was put into effect.
  • In 1911, King George V announced at Delhi Durbar that eastern Bengal would be assimilated into the Bengal Presidency.

question: With which one of the following movements is the slogan “Do or Die” associated? (UPSC Prelims 2009)
option_1: Swadeshi Movement
option_2: Non-Cooperation Movement
option_3: Civil Disobedience Movement
option_4: Quit India Movement
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • The slogan “Do or Die” is associated with the Quit India Movement. Mahatma Gandhi gave the slogan during his QuitIndia speech on August 8, 1942, at the Gowalia Tank Maidan in Bombay. The Indian National Congress (INC) officially launched the slogan on August 9, 1942.
  • The Quit India Movement, also known as the August Movement or August Kranti Movement, was Mahatma Gandhi’s last Civil Disobedience movement. The movement began on August 8, 1942.
  • In his speech, Gandhi called for determined, but passive resistance. He said, “Here is a Mantra, a short one that I give you. You may imprint it on your hearts and let every breath of yours give expression to it. The mantra is Do or Die. We shall either free India or die in the attempt; we shall not live to see the perpetuation of slavery”.

question:
Consider the following statements: (UPSC Prelims 2009)

The Cripps Proposals include the provision for

1. Full indepedence for India

2. Creation of Constitution making body

Which of the given above is/are correct?
option_1: 1 only
option_2: 2 only
option_3: Both 1 and 2
option_4: Neither 1 nor 2
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

The Cripps Mission proposals included the following provisions:

1. Dominion status: Create an Indian Union with Dominion status after the war

2. Constituent Assembly: Form a Constitution-making body for India after the war

3. Right to secede for the provinces: Allow any British Indian Province unwilling to accept the Constitution to either maintain its current constitutional status or frame its own constitution

4. Full independence for India: The Cripps Proposals included the provision for full independence for India after the end of the Second World War

5. Creation of a Constitution-making body: The proposals also provided for the creation of a Constitution-making body to draft a new constitution for India

  • The Cripps Mission was led by Stafford Cripps and came to India from 22 March to 11 April 1942. The proposals were rejected by the INC, the Muslim League, and other Indian groups. The British saw the proposals as too radical, and the INC saw them as too conservative.

question: In the “Individual Satyagraha”, Vinoba Bhave was chosen as the first Satyagrahi. Who was the second? (UPSC Prelims 2009)
option_1: Dr. Rajendra Prasad
option_2: Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru
option_3: C. Rajagopalachari
option_4: Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • According to 1940, Vinoba Bhave was the first Satyagrahi and Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru was the second in the Individual Satyagraha movement.
  • The Individual Satyagraha movement started on October 17, 1940, when Mahatma Gandhi inaugurated it. The movement’s centerpiece is non-violence, which is achieved by carefully selecting the Satyagrahis.

question: Who of the following is the author of a collection of poems called “Golden Threshold”? (UPSC Prelims 2009)
option_1: Aruna Asaf Ali
option_2: Annie Besant
option_3: Sarojini Naidu
option_4: Vijayalaksmi Pandit
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • The Golden Threshold is a collection of poems by Sarojini Naidu. Naidu was an Indian poet, politician, and activist who was the first Indian woman president ofthe Indian National Congress in 1925. The Golden Threshold was first published in 1905 and contains 63 poems inspired by Indian culture, mythology, and nature. The book includes folk songs, poems, and other verses such as “Palanquin-Bearers”, “Wandering Singers”, “Indian Weavers”, and “Harvest Hymn”.

question: During the freedom struggle, Aruna Asaf Ali was a major woman organizer of underground activity in............. (UPSC Prelims 2009)
option_1: Civil Disobedience Movement
option_2: Non-Cooperation
option_3: Quit India Movement
option_4: Swadeshi Movement
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • Aruna Asaf Ali was a major woman organizer of underground activity during the Quit India Movement in 1942.
  • Asaf Ali was an Indian political activist, educator, and publisher.
  • She is known as the “Grand Old Lady of Indian Independence” for her role in the freedom struggle.
  • Asaf Ali is best known for hoisting the Indian National flag at the Gowalia Tank Maidan in Bombay during the 1942 Quit India Movement. She secretly worked to organize resistance against the British rulers during this time.

question: In collaboration with David Hare and Alexander Duff, who of the following established Hindu College at Calcutta? (UPSC Prelims 2009)
option_1: Henry Louis Vivian Derozio
option_2: Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar
option_3: Keshab Chandra Sen
option_4: Raja Rammohan Roy
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • Raja Ram Mohan Roy established the Hindu College in Calcutta in 1817 in collaboration with David Hare and Alexander Duff. Roy was a social reformer who led the college’s foundation committee. The college was originally a non-government college for the sons of theHindu community, and introduced western education.
  • In 1825, Roy established Vedanta College, which offered courses in both Indian learning and Western social and physical sciences.

question:
With reference to Union Government, consider the following statements: (UPSC Prelims 2009)

1. The number of Ministries at the Centre on 15th August 1947 was 18.

2. The number of Ministries at the Centre at present is 36.

Which of the statements given above is are correct?
option_1: 1 only
option_2: 2 only
option_3: Both 1 and 2
option_4: Neither 1 nor 2
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • On August 15, 1947, the Government of India had 18 ministries. Jawaharlal Nehru became India’s first Prime Minister on August 15, 1947, and formed the First Nehru ministry with 15 ministers.

The Council of Ministers (COM) has three types of ministers:

1. Ministers of state

2. Deputy ministers

3. Cabinet ministers

  • The President appoints cabinet ministers on the advice of the Prime Minister. Cabinet ministers play a key role in shaping the country’s governance and development.
  • Currently, There are 54 Union ministries and 93 departments in India.

question: Who of the following Prime Ministers sent Cripps Mission to India? (UPSC Prelims 2009)
option_1: James Ramsay MacDonaldd
option_2: Stanley Baldwin
option_3: Neville Chamberlain
option_4: Winston Churchill
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • In March 1942, British Prime Minister Winston Churchill sent Stafford Cripps to India to negotiate an agreement with Indian leaders. The mission was part of the Churchill government’s efforts to secure Indian cooperation and support for the British war effort in World War II.
  • Cripps was a senior minister in the Labour Party, which traditionally supported Indian self-rule. However, he was also a member of the War Cabinet, which was led by Churchill, who had long been against Indian independence.
  • The mission’s proposals were drafted by Cripps with Indian leaders, including nationalist Congress leaders and Muhammad Ali Jinnah and the Muslim League. The proposals included promises of elections and self-government after the war if India remained loyal to the British war effort. However, the Congress rejected the proposals because they knew the British were negotiating from a weaker position.

question: During the Indian Freedom Struggle, why did Rowlatt Act arouse popular indignation? (UPSC Prelims 2009)
option_1: It curtailed the freedom of religion
option_2: It suppressed the Indian traditional education
option_3: It authorized the government to imprison people without trial
option_4: It curbed the trade union activities
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

The Rowlatt Act of 1919 aroused popular indignation during the Indian Freedom Struggle because it:

1. Restricted civil liberties :

  • The act restricted freedom of expression, speech, and assembly. It also curbed trade union activities.

2. Gave the government autocratic powers :

  • The act gave the government the power to repress political activities and detain political prisoners without a trial for two years.

3. Was undemocratic and oppressive :

  • The act was opposed by Indian leaders, including Mahatma Gandhi, who called it a violation of human rights and an attack on Indian nationalism.
  • Hurriedly passed through the Imperial Legislative Council
  • The act was completely opposed by Indian members.

question:
Consider the following statements: (UPSC Prelims 2009)

1. The discussions in the Third Round Table Conference eventually led to the passing of the Government of India Act of 1935.

2. The Government of India Act of 1935 provided for the establishment of an All India Federation to be based on a Union of the provinces of British India and the Princely States.

Which of the above statements is/are correct?
option_1: 1 only
option_2: 2 only
option_3: Both 1 and 2
option_4: Neither 1 nor 2
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • The discussions in the Third Round Table Conference led to the passing of the Government of India Act of 1935.
  • The third round table conference was held in London from November 17 to December 24, 1932. The conference was short and unimportant, as neither the Congress nor the British Labour Party attended.
  • The conference’s recommendations were published in a White Paper in 1933, which was later discussed in the British Parliament. The recommendations were analyzed, and the Government of India Act of 1935 was passed on its basis. The act establishes provincial autonomy, a federal system, and an All-India Federation. The federation is based on a union of the provinces of British India and the Princely States.
  • The Government of India Act of 1935 provided for the establishment of an All India Federation. This federation would be based on a union of the provinces of British India and the Princely States.

question: For the Karachi session of Indian National Congress in 1931, presided over by Sardar Patel, who drafted the Resolution on Fundamental Rights and Economic Programme? (UPSC Prelims 2010)
option_1: Mahatma Gandhi
option_2: Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru
option_3: Dr. Rajendra Prasad
option_4: Dr. B. R. Ambedkar
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • In 1931, Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel presided over the 46th session of the Indian National Congress in Karachi.
  • Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, a prominent leader in the Congress at the time, drafted the resolution on fundamental rights and economic program.

1. Fundamental rights :

  • The resolution guarantees freedom of speech, press, and assembly, the right to form associations, universal adult franchise, and equal legal rights

2. National economic program :

  • The resolution includes a substantial reduction in rent and revenue, and exemption from rent for uneconomic holdings

question: Who among the following were official Congress negotiators with Cripps Mission? (UPSC Prelims 2010)
option_1: Mahatma Gandhi and Sardar Patel
option_2: Acharya J. B. Kripalani and C. Rajagopalachari
option_3: Pandit Nehru and Maulana Azad
option_4: Dr. Rajendra Prasad and Rafi Ahmed Kidwai
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • Pandit Nehru and Maulana Azad were Congress negotiators with Cripps’ Mission.
  • In late March 1942, the British government sent Stafford Cripps, a member of the Labour Party, to negotiate with Indian leaders to gain their support for World War II. The meetings, known as the Cripps Mission, took place in Delhi from March 22 to April 12, 1942.

Cripps’ proposals included:

1. Keeping India loyal to the British war effort

2. A promise of elections and full self government once the war was over

3. Dominion Status to India

4. An electoral body in India

  • The Congress rejected Cripps’ proposals because they knew the British were negotiating from a weaker position.

question: With reference to Simon Commission’s recommendations, which one of the following statements is correct? (UPSC Prelims 2010)
option_1: It recommended the replacement of diarchy with responsible government in the provinces
option_2: It proposed the setting up of inter- provincial council under the Home Department
option_3: It suggested the abolition of bicameral legislature at the Centre
option_4: It recommended the creation of Indian Police Service, with a provision for increased pay and allowances for British recruits as compared to Indian recruits
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • Simon Commission came in 1927.
  • Diarchy was proposed in the Government of India Act, 1919. It was replaced with the Provincial Autonomy in the Government of India Act, 1935.
  • The recommendations of the Simon Commission were published in May 1930.
  • Dyarchy in the provinces should be abolished and ministers should be made responsible to the provincial legislatures in all departments, including the department of law and order.
  • The Governor was to retain the special powers for the safety and tranquility of the province and for the protection of the minorities.
  • He would also have full powers of intervention in the event of a breakdown of the constitution.
  • The Franchise was to be extended and legislatures were to be enlarged.
  • At the center, a Federal assembly would be constituted on the basis of representation of the provinces and other areas as per the population.
  • The council of state would continue as the Upper House but its members would be chosen not on the basis of the direct election but on the basis of indirect election by the Provincial councils.
  • No change in the central executive.
  • The All-India Federation was not considered a practical idea for immediate execution.
  • Burma should be separated from British India and should be provided a constitution of its own.

question: After Quit India Movement, C. Rajagopalachari issued a pamphlet entitled ‘The Way Out”. Which one of the following was a proposal in this pamphlet? (UPSC Prelims 2010)
option_1: The establishment of a “War Advisory Council composed of representatives of British India and the Indian States
option_2: Reconstitution of the Central Executive Council in such a way that all its members, except the Governor General and the Commander-in Chief should be Indian leaders
option_3: Fresh elections to the Central and Provincial Legislatures to be held at the end of 1945 and the Constitution making body to be convened as soon as possible
option_4: A solution for the constitutional deadlock
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • C. Rajagopalachari’s pamphlet The Way Out proposed a solution to the constitutional deadlock in 1944 during the Quit India Movement. The pamphlet also proposed a formula for cooperation between the Congress and the League.
  • In the last years of the war, Rajagopalachari was involved in negotiations between Jinnah and Gandhi. He opposed Gandhi during the Quit India Movement, believing the British would eventually leave the country and that launching another Satyagraha was not a good idea.

question: Four resolutions were passed at the famous Calcutta session of Indian National Congress in 1906. The question of either retention OR of rejection of these four resolutions became the cause of a split in Congress at the next Congress session held in Surat in 1907. Which one of the following was not one of those resolutions? (UPSC Prelims 2010)
option_1: Annulment of partition of Bengal
option_2: Boycott
option_3: National education
option_4: Swadeshi
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • The congress was compelled by the extremists to adopt following resolutions which were accepted by the moderates with half heart.

These were as follows :

1. Resolution on Partition of Bengal

2. Resolution of Self Government (Swaraj)

3. Resolution on Swadeshi

4. Resolution on Boycott.

  • Thus in Calcutta session of 1906, under the leadership of Dadabhai Naoroji, Congress adopted Swara) as the Goal of Indian people.

question: What was the immediate cause for the launch of the Swadeshi movement? (UPSC Prelims 2010)
option_1: The partition of Bengal done by Lord Curzon
option_2: A sentence of 18 months rigorous imprisonment imposed on Lokmanya Tilak
option_3: The arrest and deportation of LalaLajpat Rai and Ajit Singh and passing of the Punjab Colonization Bill
option_4: Death sentence pronounced on the Chapekar brothers
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • The Swadeshi movement was a protest against the British government’s decision to partition Bengal in July 1905. The movement’s immediate cause is the partition of Bengal by the Viceroy of India, Lord Curzon.

The Swadeshi movement’s other causes include:

1. Curbing foreign goods: The movement’s goal is to rely on domestic production instead of buying foreign goods.

2. Revival of domestic products: The movement calls for boycotting British products and buying Indian products instead.

3. Promoting indigenous industries: The movement’s goal is to promote indigenous industries.

  • The movement’s size and shape is due to donations from wealthy Indians who dedicated money and land to Khadi and Gramodyog societies. These societies start cloth production in every household.
  • Balgangadhar Tilak coined the term “Bahishkar Yoga” to describe the movement.

question: Who among the following Governor Generals created the Covenanted Civil Service of India which later came to be known as the Indian Civil Service? (UPSC Prelims 2010)
option_1: Warren Hastings
option_2: Wellesley
option_3: Cornwallis
option_4: William Bentinck
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • British General Charles Cornwallis (1786 1793) is known as the “Father of Civil Service in India”. Cornwallis was appointed in February 1786 as the Governor of the Presidency of Fort William and Commander-in-Chief of British India.
  • He is known for creating the Covenanted Civil Service and the Uncovenanted Civil Service, which later became the Indian Civil Service. Cornwallis established competitive examinations in England to select candidates for the Covenanted Civil Service, which were open to both British and Indian candidates.

question:
Consider the following statements: (UPSC Prelims 2010)

1. The “Bombay Manifesto” signed in 1936 openly opposed the preaching of socialist ideals.

2. It evoked support from a large section of business community from all across India.

Which of the statements given above is/ are correct?
option_1: 1 only
option_2: 2 only
option_3: Both 1 and 2
option_4: Neither 1 nor 2
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • The Bombay manifesto sign in 1936 by 21 Bombay businessman, contained an open indictment of Nehru’s preaching of socialist ideals, which were deemed prejudicial to private property and to the peace and prosperity of the nation. Although it did not evoke support from any other section of the business community it strengthened the hands of moderates within the Congress to put pressure on Nehru to tone down his socialist utterances.

question: By a regulation in 1793, the District Collector was deprived of his judicial powers and made the collecting agent only. What was the reason for such regulation? (UPSC Prelims 2010)
option_1: Lord Cornwallis felt that the District Collector’s efficiency of revenue collection would enormously increase without the burden of other work
option_2: Lord Cornwallis felt that Judicial power should compulsorily be in the hands of Europeans while Indians can be given the job of revenue collection in the districts
option_3: Lord Cornwallis was alarmed at the extent of power concentrated in the district collector and felt that such absolute power was undesirable in one person
option_4: The judicial work demanded a deep knowledge of India and a good training in law and Lord Cornwallis felt that District Collector should be only a revenue collector
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • Lord Cornwallis felt that the district collector’s efficiency of revenue collection would enormously increase without the burden of other work. By a regulation in 1793, the district collector was deprived of his judicial powers and made the collecting agent only.

question:
Consider the following statements: (UPSC Prelims 2010)

1. Dr. Rajendra Prasad persuaded Mahatma Gandhi to come to Champaran to investigate the problem of peasants.

2. Acharya J. B. Kripalani was one of Mahatma Gandhi’s colleagues in his Champaran investigation.

Which of the statements given above is/ are correct?
option_1: 1 only
option_2: 2 only
option_3: Both 1 and 2
option_4: Neither 1 nor 2
solution_text:

  • Shukla invited Gandhi to Champaran to investigate the problems faced by the peasants and to begin a satyagraha movement. Gandhi’s colleagues in this movement included JB Kriplani, Rajendra Prasad, Mazhar-ulHaq, Mahadeo Desai, and Narhari Parekh.
  • In 1914 and 1916, farmers revolted against the government in indigo plant cultivation. The Champaran Satyagraha of 1917 was an important event in the Indian freedom struggle. It marked Gandhi’s first appearance in Indian politics as a leader of the masses.
  • Acharya J.B. Kripalani was a colleague of Mahatma Gandhi during the Champaran investigation. Kripalani was a prominent Indian educator, social activist, and politician who supported Gandhi’s ideology. The two met in Santiniketan after Gandhi’s return from South Africa.
  • Kripalani was one of many fellow nationalists who supported and worked with Gandhi during the Champaran Satyagraha. Gandhi arrived in Champaran on April 10, 1917 with a team of lawyers, including Kripalani. The Lieutenant Governor in Council convened a Committee of Inquiry to investigate the agrarian situation in Champaran, and Gandhi was named as a member

question: The tendency for increased litigation was visible after the introduction of the land settlement system of Lord Cornwallis in 1793. The reason for this is normally traced to which of the following provisions? (UPSC Prelims 2011)
option_1: Making Zamindar’s position stronger vis-à-vis the ryot

Other reasons for increased litigation include:

1. Lawyers were required to prescribe their fees

2. Ordinary people could sue government servants if they made mistakes

3. Inhuman punishments were abolished, such as cutting limbs, nose, and ears

question:
With reference to the period of colonial rule in India, “Home Charges” formed an important part of the drain of wealth from India. Which of the following funds constituted “Home Charges”? (UPSC Prelims 2011)

question: What was the purpose for which Sir William Wedderburn and W.S. Caine had set up the Indian Parliamentary Committee in 1893? (UPSC Prelims 2011)
option_1: To agitate for Indian political reforms in the House of Commons

question: Which amongst the following provided a common factor for tribal insurrection in India in the 19th century? (UPSC Prelims 2011)
option_1: Introduction of a new system of land revenue and taxation of tribal products
option_2: Influence of foreign religious missionaries in tribal areas
option_3: Rise of a large number of money lenders, traders and revenue farmers as middlemen in tribal areas
option_4: The complete disruption of the old agrarian order of the tribal communities
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • The most common factor for tribal insurrection in India in the 19th century was the disruption of the old agrarian order of the tribal communities.

Here are some other factors that contributed to tribal uprisings in the 19th century:

1. Land laws :

  • The British land settlements and land laws created tensions in the tribal society.

2. Forest laws :

  • The British enforcement of the Forest Act disrupted the way of life of tribal communities.

3. Agriculture :

  • The loss of agricultural land by the tribals, restrictions on the use of forest produce, and the introduction of money lenders contributed to tribal revolts.

4. Economy :

  • The fast changes made by the Britishers in the economy, government, and land revenue structure caused the agricultural society to be disrupted.

5. Non-tribals :

  • Non-tribals had started entering forests and clearing land for settled agriculture, disturbing the lives of tribal communities.

6. Protection of traditions :

  • Another major reason for tribal uprisings during colonial British rule was the protection of their traditions and customs.

question:
What was the reason for Mahatma Gandhi to organise a satyagraha on behalf of the peasants of Kheda? (UPSC Prelims 2011)

1. The Administration did not suspend the land revenue collection in spite of a drought.

2. The Administration proposed to introduce Permanent Settlement in Gujarat.

Which of the statements given above is/ are correct?
option_1: 1 only
option_2: 2 only
option_3: Both 1 and 2
option_4: Neither 1 nor 2
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • Mahatma Gandhi organized a satyagraha in 1918 in the Kheda district of Gujarat to support peasants who were unable to pay land taxes due to crop failure and poverty.

The peasants were unable to pay the taxes because of:

1. Excessive taxes

2. A plague outbreak that made them unable to work

3. A severe drought that led to crop failures

4. Widespread distress among peasant communities

  • Satyagraha is a form of nonviolent resistance or civil resistance that means “holding firmly to truth” or “truth force”. Gandhi developed the term and practiced it in the Indian independence movement and in his earlier struggles in South Africa for Indian rights.

The Permanent Settlement :

  • It is also known as the Permanent Settlement of Bengal, was an agreement between the East India Company and the landlords of Bengal in 1793. The agreement was part of the Cornwallis Code, a larger body of legislation that divided the East India Company’s service personnel into three branches.

The Permanent Settlement had several features:

1. The agreement established a fixed amount of revenue to be collected from land.

2. The agreement stated that the amount to be given to the government was fixed permanently.

3. The agreement gave zamindars the power to collect revenue.

4. The agreement recognized zamindars as the permanent owners of the land.

5. The agreement instructed zamindars to pay 89% of the annual revenue to the state and keep 11% as their share.

6. The agreement encouraged zamindars to invest in improving lands.

7. The agreement created an Indian landed class that supported British authority.

  • The Permanent Settlement was first enacted in Bengal, Bihar, and Odisha in 1793 by the Governor-General Lord Cornwallis. It was later followed in the presidency of northern Madras and in the Varanasi district. The regulations remained in place until the Charter Act of 1833.

question: Which one of the following observations is not true about the Quit India Movement of 1942? (UPSC Prelims 2011)

question: With reference to Indian freedom struggle, Usha Mehta is well-known for............ (UPSC Prelims 2011)
option_1: Running the secret Congress Radio in the wake of Quit India Movement
option_2: Participating in the second round Table Conference
option_3: Leading a contingent of Indian National Army
option_4: Assisting in the formation of Interim Government under Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru
solution_text:

  • On August 14, 1942, Mehta and some of her associates began the clandestine radio station, which went on air on August 27, 1942. The station was a vital communication tool during the Quit India movement, a key phase of the Indian independence struggle. The station’s messages included messages to students, workers, peasants, and Indian soldiers, directing them to participate in the Quit India Movement. The station also preached internationalism and spread the message of the Indian movement beyond the country.
  • Mehta was born on March 25, 1920 in the village of Saras, near Surat in Gujarat. She was fluent in four languages, including English, Gujarati, Hindi, and Marathi. She adopted a Gandhian lifestyle by wearing only Khadi clothes and shunning luxuries.
  • Sarojini Naidu represented Indian women at the Second Round Table Conference, which was held in London from September 7, 1931 to December 1, 1931. Naidu was a follower of Mahatma Gandhi and a participant in the national movement.

Other participants at the conference included:

2. Hindus: MR Jayakar, Depressed Classes: Dr BR Ambedkar

question:
With reference to Ryotwari Settlement, consider the following statements: (UPSC Prelims 2012)

1. The rent was paid directly by the peasants to the Government.

2. The government gave Pattas to the Ryots.

3. The lands were surveyed and assessed before being taxed.

Which of the statements given above is/ are correct?
option_1: 1 only
option_2: 1 and 2 only
option_3: 1, 2 and 3
option_4: None
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • In the Ryotwari system, peasants pay rent directly to the government.
  • In the Ryotwari system, the government collects taxes directly from peasants, who are known as ryots. The system was introduced in British India by Thomas Munro.
  • In the Ryotwari system, the government gives pattas to the ryots, which are written agreements between the peasant and the zamindar that record the amount of rent to be paid. The tax rates are 50% in dryland and 60% in wetland.

The Ryotwari system allows peasants to:

1. Sell, mortgage, or gift the land

2. Cede or acquire new land for cultivation

  • However, the Ryotwari system ignores customary occupancy rights and reduces peasants to the status of tenants.
  • The government gave pattas to the ryots in the Ryotwari system, a land revenue system in British India. The pattas were registered agreements that recognized the ryots’ ownership rights and their rights to cultivate the land and required lands to be surveyed and assessed before being taxed. The system was used in some parts of British India to collect revenue from cultivators.
  • In the Ryotwari system, the government dealt directly with the cultivators, known as ryots, for revenue collection. The ryots were peasant cultivators who paid rent directly to the government. The land was taxed at a rate of 50% in dryland and 60% in wetland.

question:

question:
Which of the following is/are the principal feature(s) of the Government of India Act, 1919? (UPSC Prelims 2012)

1. Introduction of diarchy in the executive government of the provinces.

2. Introduction of separate communal electorates for Muslims.

3. Devolution of legislative authority by the centre to the provinces.

Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
option_1: 1 only
option_2: 2 and 3 only
option_3: 1 and 3 only
option_4: 1, 2 and 3
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • The Government of India Act of 1919 introduced dyarchy, a system of dual government, for the provinces of British India. Dyarchy is a two-person rule consisting of executive councillors and popular ministers. The governor would serve as the province’s executive head.

The act divided subjects into two categories:

1. reserved and

2. transferred.

Reserved subjects included:

i) Finance

ii) Irrigation

iii) Law and order

iv) Land revenue

 Transferred subjects included:

i) Local government

ii) Health

iii) Education

iv) Excise

v) Industry.

  • The act also introduced bicameralism and direct election for the first time in India. It provided for the establishment of a public service commission which was set up in 1926.
  • The Government of India Act, 1919 (GIAA) is a document that provides for the devolution of legislative authority from the central government to the provinces.
  • The GIAA also expands the powers and responsibilities of the central and provincial legislatures.

The GIAA’s main features include:

1. Devolution of legislative authority :

  • The GIAA provides for the devolution of some legislative authority from the central government to the provincial governments. Separation of central and provincial subjects
  • The GIAA loosens central control over the provinces by separating and demarcating the central and provincial subjects.

2. Expansion of legislatures :

  • The GIAA expands and reconstitutes both the Central and Provincial legislatures, giving them more powers and responsibilities.
  • The GIAA also prohibits judicial review.
  • The Indian Councils Act of 1909, also known as the Morley-Minto Reforms, introduced separate electorates for Muslims. Under this act, Muslim members were to be elected only by Muslim voters. The act is considered to have “legalized communalism” by introducing electorates based solely on religion.
  • The separate electorate was extended to Sikhs, Indian Christians, Anglo-Indians, and Europeans by the Government of India Act of 1919.

question: The distribution of powers between the Centre and the States in the Indian Constitution is based on the scheme provided in the.............. (UPSC Prelims 2012)
option_1: Morley-Minto Reforms, 1909
option_2: Montagu-Chelmsford Act, 1919
option_3: Government of India Act, 1935
option_4: Indian Independence Act, 1947

Explanation : (C)

  • The distribution of powers between the center and the states in the Indian Constitution is based on the Government of India Act, 1935. The act is a detailed document with 321 sections and 10 schedules. The distribution of legislative powers is based on three lists under the Seventh Schedule.

 The act also provides for a three-fold enumeration:

1. federal

2. provincial and

3. concurrent.

  • However, under the act, residuary powers are given to the governor-general of India, not the federal or provincial legislature.
  • The Constitution of India was adopted by the Constituent Assembly on November 26, 1949 and came into force on January 26, 1950.

question: During the Indian freedom struggle, the National Social Conference was formed. What was the reason for its formation? (UPSC Prelims 2012)
option_1: Different social reform groups or organizations of the Bengal region united to form a single body to discuss the issues of larger interest and to prepare appropriate petitions/ representations to the government.
option_2: Indian National Congress did not want to include social reforms in its deliberations and decided to form a separate body for such a purpose.
option_3: Behramji Malabari and M.G. Ranade decided to bring together all the social reform groups of the country under one organization.
option_4: None of the statements (a), (b) and (c) given above is correct in this context.
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • The National Social Conference was founded by M.G. Ranade and Raghunath Rao in December 1887. The conference was a social reform cell of the Indian National Congress, and met annually at the same time and place as the Congress.
  • The conference’s first session was held in Madras in December 1887. The conference advocated for intercaste marriages and opposed kulinism and polygamy. It also launched the “Pledge Movement” to encourage people to prohibit child marriage.
  • The conference’s purpose was to promote the discussion of social issues on a national scale. However, the conference’s reason for existence disappeared when the Congress appropriated much of its program and was led by a more capable and popular leader.
  • Ranade was an Indian scholar, social reformer, judge, and author. He has been referred to as the “Father of Indian Economics” because of his unsuccessful efforts to persuade the British government to launch state welfare and industrialization programs.

question:
Which of the following statements is/are correct regarding Brahmo Samaj? (UPSC Prelims 2012)

1. It opposed idolatry.

2. It denied the need for a priestly class for interpreting the religious texts.

3. It popularized the doctrine that the Vedas are infallible.

Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
option_1: 1 only
option_2: 1 and 2 only
option_3: 3 only
option_4: 1, 2 and 3
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • The correct statements about Brahmo Samaj are that it opposed idolatry and denied the need for a priestly class for interpreting religious texts.
  • Brahmo Samaj was a socio-religious reform movement founded by Raja Ram Mohan Roy in 1828. It was a monotheistic sect of Hinduism that believed in an infinite singularity, which is considered infinite, indivisible, imperceptible, and undefinable. Brahmo Samaj rejected avatars, reincarnation, and rebirths, andcondemned idolatry and polytheism. It also supported a more rational and reformist approach to religion, and did not uphold the infallibility of the Vedas.
  • Hence statement 3 is not correct. Debendranath Tagore, the father of Rabindranath Tagore, was a key member of the Brahmo Sabha. In 1843 he was involved in the creation of the Brahmo Samaj.
  • Keshub Chunder Sen, a disciple of Tagore, joined the Samaj in 1857 but broke away in a formal schism in 1866. This schism was called the Brahmo Samaj of India.

question: The Rowlatt Act aimed at.............. (UPSC Prelims 2012)
option_1: Compulsory economic support to war efforts
option_2: Imprisonment without trial and summary procedures for trial
option_3: Suppression of the Khilafat Movement.
option_4: Imposition of restrictions on freedom of the press.
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • The Rowlatt Act was passed by the British government in March 1919 to limit the fundamental rights of Indian citizens and suppress political activities. The act gave the police the power to arrest anyone without cause.
  • The Rowlatt Act was met with opposition from Indians, who saw it as undemocratic and oppressive. The act also strengthened police powers and limited freedom of expression.
  • Mahatma Gandhi called for a non-violent Satyagraha against the act, which began on April 6, 1919.

The Khilafat Movement :

  • It was a political campaign that ran from 1919–1924. It was a pan-Islamic movement led by Indian Muslims to pressure the British government to preserve the Ottoman Sultan’s authority as Caliph of Islam. The movement’s goal was to save the Ottoman caliph as a symbol of unity among the Muslim community in India.
  • The movement was initially supported by Gandhi’s noncooperation movement. However, it fell apart after the abolition of the caliphate in 1924. The movement was abruptly called off on February 12, 1922, at Gandhiji’s insistence, proceeding with the news of the Chauri Chaura incident.
  • The term “caliph” (khalifah in Arabic) is generally regarded to mean “successor of the prophet Muhammad,” while “caliphate” (khilafah in Arabic) denotes the office of the political leader of the Muslim community (ummah) or state.

The Vernacular Press Act :

  • It was a law passed in 1878 in British India to limit the freedom of the Indian-language press. The act was also known as “The Gagging Act”.
  • The act was proposed by Lord Lytton, who was the viceroy of India from 1876 1880. The act was intended to prevent the vernacular press from criticizing British policies, especially the opposition that grew during the Second Anglo-Afghan War (1878–1880). The act did not apply to English-language publications.
  • The act was modeled on the Irish Press laws and gave the government the power to censor reports and editorials in the Vernacular Press. The act also allowed the British government to confiscate newspaper assets, including printing presses and other media.

The act violated freedom of expression in the following ways:

1. Censorship :

  • The government had the power to censor reports and editorials in the Vernacular Press.

2. Seizure :

  • If a newspaper published a seditious report and did not heed an initial warning, the press was seized and the printing machinery confiscated.

question:

question: Mahatma Gandhi undertook fast unto death in 1932, mainly because............... (UPSC Prelims 2012)
option_1: Round Table Conference failed to satisfy Indian political aspirations.
option_2: Congress and Muslim League had differences of opinion.
option_3: Ramsay Macdonald announced the Communal Award.
option_4: None of the statements (a),(b) and (c) given above is correct in this context
solution_text:

question: The Ilbert Bill controversy was related to the................ (UPSC Prelims 2013)

option_3: Removal of disqualifications imposed on the Indian magistrates with regard to the trial of the Europeans
option_4: Removal of a duty on imported cotton cloth

question: The demand for the Tebhaga Peasant Movement in Bengal was for.............. (UPSC Prelims 2013)

  • The movement was initiated by Kisan Sabha in Bengal. The tenants made all the investments and labor, so the landowners should only receive one-third of the crops. The movement demanded that sharecroppers receive two-thirds of the produce and landlords receive one-third.
  • The movement turned violent in many areas, and landlords fled.
  • The Partition of Bengal and the promises of the new government led to the suspension of the movement.

question: The people of India agitated against the arrival of the Simon Commission because................ (UPSC Prelims 2013)

question:

question: The Partition of Bengal made by Lord Curzon in 1905 lasted until............... (UPSC Prelims 2014)

  • The partition was met with widespread protests and opposition, leading to its eventual reversal in 1911. The nationalists saw the partition as a challenge to Indian nationalism and as a deliberate attempt to divide the Bengal Presidency on religious grounds.

question: The Radcliffe Committee was appointed to............. (UPSC Prelims 2014)

The Radcliffe Line was revealed on August 17, 1947, and extends from the Rann of Kutch in Gujarat to the international border in Jammu in Jammu & Kashmir

question: The Government of India Act of 1919 clearly defined.............. (UPSC Prelims 2015)
option_1: The separation of power between the judiciary and the legislature.
option_2: The jurisdiction of the central and provincial governments.
option_3: The powers of the Secretary of State for India and the Viceroy
option_4: None of the above
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • The British Government declared for the first time on August 20, 1917, that its objective was the gradual introduction of responsible Government in India.
  • The Government of India Act of 1919 was enacted, which came into force in 1921.
  • This Act is also known as Montagu- Chelmsford Reforms (Montagu was the Secretary of State for India and Lord Chelmsford was the Viceroy of India).

The features of this Act were as follows:

  • It relaxed the central control over the provinces by demarcating and separating the central and provincial subjects.
  • The central and provincial legislatures were authorized to make laws on their respective list of subjects.
  • The structure of the government continued to be centralized and unitary.
  • It further divided the provincial subjects into two parts–

1. transferred and

2. reserved.

  • The transferred subjects were to be administered by the Governor with the aid of Ministers responsible to the legislative council.
  • The reserved subjects were to be administered by the Governor and his executive council without being responsible to the legislative council.
  • This dual scheme of governance was known as ‘dyarchy’–a term derived from the Greek word diarche which means the double rule.
  • It introduced, for the f irst time, bicameralism and direct elections in the country. The Indian legislative council was replaced by a bicameral legislature consisting of an Upper House (Council of State) and a Lower House (Legislative Assembly).
  • The majority of members of both the Houses were chosen by direct election. It granted franchises to a limited number of people based on property, tax, or education.
  • It required that the three of the six members of the Viceroy’s Executive Council (other than the Commander-in-Chief) were to be Indian.
  • It extended the principle of communal representation by providing separate electorates for Sikhs, Indian Christians, Anglo-Indians, and Europeans.
  • It created a new office of the High Commissioner for India in London and transferred to him some of the functions hitherto performed by the Secretary of State for India.
  • It provided for the establishment of a public service commission.
  • Hence, a Central Public Service Commission was set up in 1926 for recruiting civil servants. It separated, for the first time, provincial budgets from the Central budget and authorized the provincial legislatures to enact their budgets.
  • It provided for the appointment of a statutory commission to inquire into and report on its working after ten years of its coming into force.

question: Which one of the following movements has contributed to a split in the Indian National Congress resulting in the emergence of ‘moderates’ and ‘extremists’? (UPSC Prelims 2015)

option_4: Civil Disobedience Movement

question:

question:
With reference to the Cabinet Mission, which of the following statements is/are correct? (UPSC Prelims 2015)

option_2: 2 and 3

The mission proposed a federal structure with a weak center and strong provinces to accommodate the diverse interests of India’s communities. The central government would have limited powers, and the rest would be given to the provincial governments.
  • The Cabinet Mission also proposed a Constituent Assembly made up of representatives from the Provincial Assemblies and the Princely states. Each province would be given a number of seats based on its population.

  • The Cabinet Mission did not address the issue of enlarging the powers of Indian courts.

  • The Cabinet Mission proposed that the Indian Civil Service (ICS) should be Indianized gradually over a period of ten years.

question:

question: The Montague-Chelmsford Proposals were related to............. (UPSC Prelims 2016)

option_2: educational reforms
option_3: reforms in police administration
option_4: constitutional reforms
solution_text:

  • The Montague-Chelmsford Proposals were a set of constitutional reforms introduced in 1919. The proposals aimed to introduce a system of responsible government in British India.

The proposals included the following key provisions:

1. The Imperial Legislative Council would consist of two houses:

i) the Central Legislative Assembly and

ii) the Council of State.

2. The provinces would follow the Dual Government System or dyarchy.

  • The proposals were introduced by Edwin Montagu, the Secretary of State for India, after he visited India in 1917 and held talks with representatives of Indian polity, including Mahatma Gandhi and Muhammad Ali Jinnah. Montagu and the Governor-General of India, Lord Chelmsford, brought out a detailed report titled Constitutional Reforms in India, also called the Montagu-Chelmsford Report.
  • The report went before Cabinet on May 24 and June 7, 1918 and was embodied in the Government of India Act of 1919. The act was passed in 1919 when Lloyd George was the Prime Minister of England.

question: Satya Shodhak Samaj organized.............. (UPSC Prelims 2016)
option_1: A movement for upliftment of tribals in Bihar
option_2: A temple-entry movement in Gujarat
option_3: An anti-caste movement in Maharashtra
option_4: A peasant movement in Punjab
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • The Satya Shodhak Samaj (Truth Seekers’ Society) was a social reform society founded in 1873 by Jyotirao Phule. The organization’s goal was to liberate the lower castes from oppression and exploitation. The movement aimed to eradicate caste based discrimination and promote social equality.
  • The organization’s leadership consisted of members of the lower classes, including malis, telis, wearers of saris, kunbis, and dhangars. The movement sought to create social awareness and promote the ideas of equality, liberty, and fraternity.
  • The upper-caste leaders of Maharashtra disliked the Samaj’s friendly relations with Christian missionaries and its appeals to the British Raj.

Anti-Caste Movement in Maharashtra:

  • The Satya Shodhak Samaj launched an anti-caste movement in Maharashtra to combat the social evils of casteism and untouchability.
  • The movement aimed to create social awareness among the masses and to promote the idea of equality, liberty, and fraternity.
  • The movement challenged the Brahminical hegemony and criticized the caste system, which had kept the lower castes in a state of subjugation for centuries.
  • It advocated inter-caste marriages and the abolition of the caste system.
  • Jyotirao Phule, the founder of the movement, emphasized the need for education and economic empowerment of the lower castes.
  • He established schools and educational institutions for the education of Dalits and other marginalize communities.
  • He also encouraged them to take up vocational training and learn new skills to improve their economic condition.
  • Satya Shodhak Samaj played a pivotal role in the social reform movement in Maharashtra and inspired many other social reformers like B.R. Ambedkar, who later became the architect of the Indian Constitution.
  • Satya Shodhak Samaj was a significant social reform movement that contributed to the upliftment of the oppressed and marginalized sections of society.
  • The anti-caste movement launched by the Samaj in Maharashtra challenged the caste system and advocated social equality and justice.
  • The movement had a profound impact on the social and political landscape of India and played a crucial role in the struggle for independence and social justice.

question:

question: What was the main reason for the split in the Indian National Congress at Surat in 1907? (UPSC Prelims 2016)
option_1: Introduction of communalism into Indian politics by Lord Minto
option_2: Extremists’ lack of faith in the capacity of the moderates to negotiate with the British Government
option_3: Foundation of Muslim League
option_4: Aurobindo Ghosh’s inability to the elected as the President of the Indian National Congress
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • The Indian National Congress split in 1907 due to differences in their approach to British rule. The two groups formed were radicals and moderates.
  • The moderates opposed boycotts, which the radicals supported. The moderates believed that boycotts involved the use of force, while the radicals were in favor of boycotts.
  • The early nationalists believed in settling minor issues with the government through deliberations, while the extremists believed in agitation, strikes, and boycotts. The moderates wanted self-rule and greater autonomy and accepted nominal British rules.
  • The extremists were completely against British rule and wanted complete independence. The Indian National Congress split and reunited in 1915.

question: The ‘Swadeshi’ and ‘Boycott’ were adopted as methods of struggle for the first time during the.............. (UPSC Prelims 2016)
option_1: Agitation against the Partition of Bengal
option_2: Home Rule Movement
option_3: Non-Cooperation Movement
option_4: Visit of the Simon Commission to India
solution_text:
Explanation : (A)

  • The Swadeshi and Boycott movements were first adopted as methods of struggle during the anti-partition agitation against Bengal in 1905.
  • The Indian National Congress launched the Swadeshi movement on August 7, 1905, at Calcutta Town Hall, Bengal, in response to the partition of Bengal by Lord Curzon in July 1905.

The movement’s main goals were to:

1. Protest British colonial policies

2. Foster Indian nationalism, unity, and self-sufficiency

3. Boycott British goods

  • The Swadeshi movement lasted six years and continued until 1911. Its chief architects include Aurobindo Ghosh, Lokmanya Bal Gangadhar Tilak, and Lala Lajpat Rai.

question: The plan of Sir Stafford Cripps envisaged that after the Second World War............. (UPSC Prelims 2016)
option_1: India should be granted complete independence
option_2: India should be partitioned into two before granting independence
option_3: India should be made a republic with the condition that she will join the Commonwealth
option_4: India should be given Dominion
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • In 1942, Stafford Cripps, a member of the British War Cabinet, was sent to India to gain support from political leaders during World War II. The Cripps Mission’s plan was to grant India Dominion status after the war, which would have given India the same status as Canada, Australia, and New Zealand.

The plan also proposed:

1. A new Indian Union with Dominion status

2. Equal treatment to Indians after the war

3. A Constitution-making body for India

4. The British monarch as the head of state

  • The Cripps Plan was a compromise between the Indian National Congress’s demands for complete independence and the British desire to retain some control over India. The Congress was not convinced with the Cripps Proposals’ promise of awarding India with a dominion status or allowing India to attain self-governance.

question:
Who among the following was/were associated with the introduction of Ryotwari Settlement in India during the British Rule? (UPSC Prelims 2017)

question: The Trade Disputes Act of 1929 provided for............. (UPSC Prelims 2017)
option_1: The participation of workers in the management of industries.
option_2: Arbitrary powers to the management to quell industrial disputes.
option_3: An intervention by the British Court in the event of a trade dispute.
option_4: A system of tribunals and a ban on strikes.
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • The Trade Disputes Act of 1929 established a system of tribunals to hear and resolve trade disputes. The tribunals were made up of independent experts, representing both employers and employees, and were intended to be impartial and fair. These tribunals had the power to make binding decisions and awards, which were enforceable in law.
  • The main objective of the Trade Disputes Act of 1929 was to establish procedures for the establishment of Courts of Inquiry and Boards of Conciliation. The Act prohibited strikes or lock-outs without notice in public utility services. It also forbade trade union activity of coercive or purely political nature and even sympathetic strikes.

question:
Consider the following statements: (UPSC Prelims 2017)

1. The Factories Act, 1881 was passed with a view to fix the wages of industrial workers and to allow the workers to form trade unions.

2. N. M. Lokhande was a pioneer in organizing the labour movement in British India.

Which of the above statements is/are correct?
option_1: 1 only
option_2: 2 only
option_3: Both 1 and 2
option_4: Neither 1 nor 2
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • The Factories Act, 1881 was passed to regulate working conditions in factories, ensure the health and safety of workers, and fix the working hours of women and children. The act did not mention fixed wages or the formation of trade unions.

The act’s other provisions include:

1. One hour of rest during working hours

2. Fencing of dangerous machinery

3. Prohibition of employment of children under seven years

4. Reduced working hours for children below 12 years

5. Four days leave in a month

6. Working hours restricted to 9 hours per day for children

7. Children under 18 must not work at night (i.e. after 8:30 p.m. and before 5:30 a.m.)

8. Children (ages 9–12) are limited to 48 hours per week

  • The Factories Act, 1881 was passed by the Governor General of India in Council on March 15, 1881.
  • Narayan Meghaji Lokhande (1848-1897) is known as the pioneer of the labor movement in India. He is also known as the “Father of the Trade Union Movement in India”.
  • In 1890, Lokhande founded the Bombay Mill Hands Association, the first trade union in India. The association was created to improve the working conditions of mill workers in Bombay, who were often exploited by their employers. Lokhande is also known for his initiatives on caste and communal issues.

question: In the context of Indian history, the principle of ‘dyarchy (diarchy)’ refers to............. (UPSC Prelims 2017)
option_1: Division of the central Legislature into two houses.
option_2: Introductions of double Government i.e., central and Statement governments.
option_3: Having two sets of rulers; One in London and another in Delhi.
option_4: Division of the subjects delegated to the provinces into two categories.
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • In the context of Indian history, the principle of dyarchy refers to the division of subjects delegated to the provinces into two categories. The Government of India Act (1919) introduced the dyarchy system of double government for the provinces of British India.

The act divided subjects into two categories:

1. Reserved: Included finance, irrigation, law and order, and land revenue

2. Transferred: Included local government, health, education, excise, and industry

  • The governor would serve as the province’s executive head, in charge of the reserved list along with his executive councillors.
  • Dyarchy is a constitutional reform introduced by Edwin Samuel Montagu in 1919. It was the first time that the democratic principle was introduced into the executive branch of the British administration of India. Dyarchy led to India’s full provincial autonomy in 1935 and independence in 1947.

question: The object of the Butler Committee of 1927 was to........... (UPSC Prelims 2017)
option_1: Define the jurisdiction of the Central and Provincial Governments.
option_2: Define the powers of the Secretary of State for India.
option_3: Impose censorship on national press.
option_4: Improve the relationship between the Government of India and the Indian States.
solution_text:
Explanation : (D)

  • The Butler Committee of 1927, also known as the Indian States Committee, was appointed to investigate and clarify the relationship between the British Raj and the rulers of Princely States. The committee’s main objective was to improve the relationship between the Government of India and the Indian States. The committee submitted its report in 1929.
  • The Indian leaders felt that the British Government of India was not doing enough to protect the interests of the Indian States and that the relationship between the two was strained.
  • The committee was chaired by Sir Harcourt Butler, a former Governor of the United Provinces, and included members from both India and Britain.
  • The committee submitted its report in 1928, which recommended a number of changes to improve the relationship between the British Government of India and the Indian States.
  •  Some of the recommendations made by the Butler Committee were: The creation of a new department to deal with the affairs of the Indian States.
  • The appointment of a Commissioner for Indian States to oversee the relationship between the British Government of India and the Indian States.
  • The establishment of a council of Indian princes to advise the British Government of India on matters relating to the Indian States.
  • The granting of more autonomy to the Indian States in matters such as education, health, and public works.
  • Overall, the Butler Committee’s recommendations were aimed at improving the relationship between the British Government of India and the Indian States and giving the Indian States more autonomy in their affairs.
  • The committee’s recommendations were implemented in the Government of India Act of 1935, which gave the Indian States more autonomy and created a new department to deal with the affairs of the Indian States.
  • The committee was appointed by Lord Irwin, the viceroy of India in 1927. The committee consisted of Sir Harcourt Butler, Prof. W.S. Holdsworth, and S.C. Peel.

question:
Consider the following pairs: (UPSC Prelims 2017)

option_1: 1 only
option_2: 1 and 3 only

option_4: 1, 2 and 3
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

  • Radhakanta Deb was the first president of the British Indian Association, established in Kolkata, India on October 29, 1851. He held the position until his death.
  • The British Indian Association was formed by merging the Bengal British India Society and the Landholders’ Society in 1851. The association’s goal was to convey Indian grievances to the British government. The association’s ideology was spread through the newspaper Hindu Patriot.

The association’s recommendations included :

1. Establishing a separate legislature

2. Separating judicial functions from executive functions

3. Reducing the salaries of higher officers

4. Abolishing charges like Akbari, salt duty, and stamp duties

  • The Madras Mahajana Sabha was founded in 1884 by M. Veeraraghavachariar, G. Subramania Iyer, and P. Ananda Charlu. The organization was a regional political group and a precursor to the Indian National Congress. The Madras Mahajana Sabha’s objectives were to free India from British rule and address Indian issues.
  • The Madras Mahajana Sabha was formerly known as the Madras Native Association, which was established in 1849 by Gazulu Lakshminarasu Chetty. The Madras Native Association’s main goal was to demand reforms in British administration and to protest any injustice done to Indians.
  • Surendranath Banerjee and Ananda Mohan Bose founded the Indian National Association, also known as the Indian Association, in 1876. The association was the first openly nationalist organization in British India.
  • The association’s objectives were to “promote the political, intellectual, and material advancement of the people by every legitimate means”. The association was a preparatory agent for the Indian National Congress.
  • The association was a nationalist political group that supported local self-government. It rivaled the British Indian Association, which it considered a reactionary body of landlords and industrialists. The association spread beyond Bengal to other parts of India but remained Bengali in character.

question: Which one of the following statements does not apply to the system of Subsidiary Alliance introduced by Lord Wellesley? (UPSC Prelims 2018)
option_1: To maintain a large standing army at others expense
option_2: To keep India safe from Napoleonic danger
option_3: To secure a fixed income for the Company
option_4: To establish British paramountcy over the Indian States
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • The statement “To secure a fixed income for the Company” does not apply to the system of Subsidiary Alliance introduced by Lord Wellesley.

The Subsidiary Alliance system had several objectives, including:

1. To establish British paramountcy over the Indian States

2. To secure a fixed income for the British East India Company

3. To keep India safe from the threat of the Napoleonic danger

  • The Subsidiary Alliance system is a policy of direct interference in the internal affairs of the allied state. The system involves Indian rulers not being allowed to have their independent armed forces. The Company army protects the Indian state, but the ruler has to pay for the “subsidiary forces”. If an Indian ruler fails to make the payment, then part of his territory is taken away as penalty.

Order in which the Indian States entered into Subsidiary Alliances :

1. Hyderabad (1798)

2. Mysore (1799 – After Tipu Sultan was defeated in the Fourth Anglo-Mysore War)

3. Tanjore (1799)

4. Awadh (1801)

5. Peshwa (Marathas) (1802)

6. Scindia (Marathas) (1803)

7. Gaekwad (Marathas) (1803)

question: Economically, one of the results of the British rule in India in the 19th century was the............. (UPSC Prelims 2018)

Other commercial crops introduced include tea, coffee, jute, sugarcane, oilseeds, black pepper, and silk. The British government also controlled most commercial plantations and transactions.

The commercialization of Indian agriculture had significant economic consequences:

question: In the Federation established by the Government of India Act of 1935, residuary powers were given to the............. (UPSC Prelims 2018)
option_1: Federal Legislature
option_2: Governor General
option_3: Provincial Legislature
option_4: Provincial Governors
solution_text:
Explanation : (B)

Residuary powers :

  • These are the powers that a government authority retains after delegating certain powers to other authorities. These powers are not mentioned in any subject of the constitution.
  • The Government of India Act of 1935 gave residuary powers to the Governor General to ensure that the central government could make laws on matters not assigned to the provinces.
  • Residuary powers are powers that are not prohibited or explicitly given by law to any government body. They are given because it is impractical to detail every act allowed to be carried out by the state in legislation.
  • Residuary powers ensure that there are no ambiguities or overlaps in the jurisdiction of various authorities. They also act as a safeguard to prevent any gaps in governance.

These powers included:

1. Establishing an All-India Federation

2. Provincial autonomy, with a Government responsible to an elected legislature

3. Redistribution of provinces and the creation of two new provinces

  • In conclusion, the Government of India Act of 1935 assigned the residuary powers to the Governor General to ensure that the central government had the power to make laws on matters that were not specifically assigned to the provinces.
  • This helped in maintaining the balance of power between the central and provincial governments.

question:
After the Santhal Uprising subsided, what was/were the measure/measures taken by the colonial government? (UPSC Prelims 2018)

1. The territories called ‘Santhal Paraganas’ were created.

2. It became illegal for a Santhal to transfer land to a non-Santhal.

Select the correct answer using the code given below:
option_1: 1 only
option_2: 2 only
option_3: Both 1 and 2
option_4: Neither 1 nor 2
solution_text:
Explanation : (C)

  • The Santhal Pargana was created in 1855 as a result of the Santhal Hul or Rebellion of 1854-55. The rebellion was led by the brothers Sido and Kanu, and was the first peasant revolt in India. The rebellion is thought to have been caused by the introduction of the Permanent Land Settlement of 1793.
  • The Santhal Pargana was created by ceding 5,500 square miles from the districts of Bhagalpur and Birbhum. The Santhal Pargana was part of the Bengal Presidency and the undivided Bihar state.
  • In 1876, the British passed the Santhal Parganas Tenancy Act, which made it illegal for a Santhal to transfer land to a non Santhal. The act was passed in response to the Santhal rebellion of 1855 against the colonial government’s feudal land tenure systems.
  • The act’s purpose is to protect the land rights of the Santhal community, which are being threatened by the encroachment of non-Santhal communities on their land.

The act has several features that differentiate it from most other tenancy laws in India:

1. Section 20 mandates that most of the land in the division is non-transferable by all means other than inheritance.

2. Section 42 empowers the sub divisional officer (SDO) to evict anyillegal possessor of agricultural land within their subdivision.

question: Which one of the following is a very significant aspect of the Champaran Satyagraha? (UPSC Prelims 2018)

question: In 1920, which of the following changed its name to “Swarajya Sabha”? (UPSC Prelims 2018)
option_1: All India Home Rule League
option_2: Hindu Mahasabha
option_3: South Indian Liberal Federation
option_4: The Servants of India Society
